nexttext: \noindent In order to obtain states that have a finite momentum and particle density in the thermodynamic limit we introduce Lagrange multipliers $\mu$ and ${\mathbf u}$ and find the unconstrained ground state of the following free energy:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="N=\int d^{2}r\ \psi^{\dagger}_{r}\psi_{r},\ {\mathbf{P}}=\int d^{2}r\ \psi^{%
\dagger}_{r}{\mathbf{p}}\psi_{r}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>N</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mi>𝐏</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐩</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent At finite carrier density the fermi surface can be shown to be an ellipse described in polar coordinates by:
prevtext: \noindent In order to obtain states that have a finite momentum and particle density in the thermodynamic limit we introduce Lagrange multipliers $\mu$ and ${\mathbf u}$ and find the unconstrained ground state of the following free energy:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle F&\displaystyle=H-\mu N-{\mathbf{u}}\cdot{\mathbf{P%
}}=\int d^{2}r\ \psi^{\dagger}_{r}h\ \psi_{r},\\
\displaystyle h&\displaystyle=v\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{p}}-\mu-{\mathbf{u}}\cdot{%
\mathbf{p}}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mi>F</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐏</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><msup><mi>d</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>r</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mpadded width="+5pt"><mi>h</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mi>h</mi></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: \noindent Here $\theta$ is the polar angle measured from the axis defined by $\mathbf{u}$, and $s=1(-1)$ for electrons (holes). The particle number and current densities can be found to be:
prevtext: \noindent At finite carrier density the fermi surface can be shown to be an ellipse described in polar coordinates by:

nexttext:
\noindent where $\beta=u/v$, and $n_D$ is the density at the Dirac point. Notice that ${\mathbf j} =(n-n_D)\mathbf{u}$, making manifest the interpretation of $\mathbf{u}$ as the average velocity for charge transport. The current density will vanish at the Dirac point. As we will see, this conclusion follows from electron-hole symmetry even in the presence of interactions. This is an striking property of Dirac fermions at the Dirac point, that, even when they are unable to relax their total momentum they can reach an equilibrium state with zero total current. This is impossible for Galilean fermions where a finite momentum density is always accompanied by a finite current density. 


{\color{blue}{\em Symmetry considerations}}---We briefly describe in this section the constraints imposed by certain symmetries of the problem. Consider the following operations:
prevtext: \noindent Here $\theta$ is the polar angle measured from the axis defined by $\mathbf{u}$, and $s=1(-1)$ for electrons (holes). The particle number and current densities can be found to be:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle n=n_{D}+\frac{s\mu^{2}}{4\pi v^{2}}\frac{1}{(1-%
\beta^{2})^{3/2}},\\
\displaystyle{\mathbf{j}}=\mathbf{u}\frac{s\mu^{2}}{4\pi v^{2}}\frac{1}{(1-%
\beta^{2})^{3/2}},\end{split}" display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>n</mi><mi>D</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mrow><mi>𝐣</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>μ</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext:
All of the above are expected to be good symmetries of the full Hamiltonian including interactions. They can be interpreted as a particle-hole conjugation (C), a time-reversal-like (T) and space-inversion-like (S) operations~\footnote{In graphene the conventional definition of time reversal and space inversion also exchange valleys, so, the symmetries here considered can be viewed as a composition with a suitable valley swap operation.}. The particle number and total momentum are however not invariant under these symmetries and their transformation properties are summarized in Table~\ref{tab}. The momentum is invariant under C, and the density is invariant under C only at the Dirac point. However the current is odd under C. This implies that at the Dirac point, the current must vanish even when averaged over a subspace of the Hilbert space with a definite momentum, showing why current carrying state are not allowed at equilibrium even if the system has a net momentum. This fact originates physically from the property that the group velocity of a single particle state in the conduction band at momentum $\mathbf{p}$ points in the opposite direction to that of a state in the valence band with the same momentum. Therefore, particle-hole excitations connecting those states can change the current without changing the momentum. Away from the Dirac point the only symmetry that leaves the particle and momentum densities unchanged is TS, but the current is even under this transformation, and hence quasi-equilibrium current-carrying states at non-zero momentum are allowed.
 
{\color{blue}{\em Mean-field theory of interacting current carrying states}}---In addition to the kinetic energy we consider an interaction term in the Hamiltonian:
prevtext:
\noindent where $\beta=u/v$, and $n_D$ is the density at the Dirac point. Notice that ${\mathbf j} =(n-n_D)\mathbf{u}$, making manifest the interpretation of $\mathbf{u}$ as the average velocity for charge transport. The current density will vanish at the Dirac point. As we will see, this conclusion follows from electron-hole symmetry even in the presence of interactions. This is an striking property of Dirac fermions at the Dirac point, that, even when they are unable to relax their total momentum they can reach an equilibrium state with zero total current. This is impossible for Galilean fermions where a finite momentum density is always accompanied by a finite current density. 


{\color{blue}{\em Symmetry considerations}}---We briefly describe in this section the constraints imposed by certain symmetries of the problem. Consider the following operations:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}\displaystyle T\psi_{r}T^{-1}&\displaystyle=i\sigma_{y}\psi_{r},%
\ TiT^{-1}=-i,\\
\displaystyle C\psi_{r}C^{-1}&\displaystyle=\sigma_{x}\psi_{r}^{\dagger},\\
\displaystyle S\psi_{r}S^{-1}&\displaystyle=\sigma_{z}\psi_{-r}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>T</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>y</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>T</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>x</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mi>r</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>S</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi/><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>σ</mi><mi>z</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ψ</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: \noindent where $\alpha,\beta$ are labels for the pseudo-spin degree of freedom of the Dirac fermion. For the Coulomb interaction we would have $v_q=2 \pi e^2/\epsilon q$, and $v_{q=0}=0$ from the neutralizing background. Let us consider the case of a finite density of holes~\footnote{The electron case is equivalent but we find slightly simpler to set up the notation for the hole side.} and assume that they form a many-body Slater determinant in which every momentum eigenstate is either empty or singly occupied:
prevtext:
All of the above are expected to be good symmetries of the full Hamiltonian including interactions. They can be interpreted as a particle-hole conjugation (C), a time-reversal-like (T) and space-inversion-like (S) operations~\footnote{In graphene the conventional definition of time reversal and space inversion also exchange valleys, so, the symmetries here considered can be viewed as a composition with a suitable valley swap operation.}. The particle number and total momentum are however not invariant under these symmetries and their transformation properties are summarized in Table~\ref{tab}. The momentum is invariant under C, and the density is invariant under C only at the Dirac point. However the current is odd under C. This implies that at the Dirac point, the current must vanish even when averaged over a subspace of the Hilbert space with a definite momentum, showing why current carrying state are not allowed at equilibrium even if the system has a net momentum. This fact originates physically from the property that the group velocity of a single particle state in the conduction band at momentum $\mathbf{p}$ points in the opposite direction to that of a state in the valence band with the same momentum. Therefore, particle-hole excitations connecting those states can change the current without changing the momentum. Away from the Dirac point the only symmetry that leaves the particle and momentum densities unchanged is TS, but the current is even under this transformation, and hence quasi-equilibrium current-carrying states at non-zero momentum are allowed.
 
{\color{blue}{\em Mean-field theory of interacting current carrying states}}---In addition to the kinetic energy we consider an interaction term in the Hamiltonian:

nexttext: \noindent Where $FS$ is the region in momentum that is singly occupied. We will minimize the energy under the constraint of fixed particle number and momentum within this set of states, and therefore our procedure can be viewed as a form of Hartree-Fock theory at finite momentum. The free energy including interactions is:
prevtext: \noindent where $\alpha,\beta$ are labels for the pseudo-spin degree of freedom of the Dirac fermion. For the Coulomb interaction we would have $v_q=2 \pi e^2/\epsilon q$, and $v_{q=0}=0$ from the neutralizing background. Let us consider the case of a finite density of holes~\footnote{The electron case is equivalent but we find slightly simpler to set up the notation for the hole side.} and assume that they form a many-body Slater determinant in which every momentum eigenstate is either empty or singly occupied:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="|\Psi\rangle=\prod_{p\in FS}\biggl{(}\sum_{\alpha}u_{p\alpha}\psi^{\dagger}_{p%
\alpha}\biggr{)}|O\rangle," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Ψ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∏</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>∈</mo><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow></mrow></munder><mrow><mrow><mo maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">(</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>α</mi></munder><mrow><msub><mi>u</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ψ</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow><mo>†</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo maxsize="210%" minsize="210%">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>O</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent where $f_p=0(1)$ if the state is empty (occupied) and $| {\mathbf n}_p\rangle$ is the state correspoing to unit vector ${\mathbf n}_p$ in the pseudo-spin Bloch sphere that is occupied at momentum $\mathbf{p}$. More explicitly, the free energy reads as:
prevtext: \noindent Where $FS$ is the region in momentum that is singly occupied. We will minimize the energy under the constraint of fixed particle number and momentum within this set of states, and therefore our procedure can be viewed as a form of Hartree-Fock theory at finite momentum. The free energy including interactions is:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle F=\sum_{p}{\rm tr}[G_{p}(v\sigma\cdot{\mathbf{p}}-%
\mu-{\mathbf{u}}\cdot{\mathbf{p}}+\Sigma_{p}/2)],\\
&\displaystyle G_{p}=f_{p}|{\mathbf{n}}_{p}\rangle\langle{\mathbf{n}}_{p}|,\ %
\Sigma_{p}=-\frac{1}{A}\sum_{p^{\prime}}v_{p-p^{\prime}}G_{p^{\prime}}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>p</mi></munder><mrow><mi>tr</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>σ</mi></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>G</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">⟨</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo rspace="7.5pt">,</mo><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Σ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>A</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></munder><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>G</mi><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

prevtext: \noindent where $f_p=0(1)$ if the state is empty (occupied) and $| {\mathbf n}_p\rangle$ is the state correspoing to unit vector ${\mathbf n}_p$ in the pseudo-spin Bloch sphere that is occupied at momentum $\mathbf{p}$. More explicitly, the free energy reads as:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle F=\sum_{p}(v{\mathbf{p}}\cdot{\mathbf{n}}_{p}-\mu-%
{\mathbf{u}}\cdot{\mathbf{p}})f_{p}\\
&\displaystyle\cdots-\frac{1}{2A}\sum_{p,p^{\prime}}v_{p-p^{\prime}}\left(%
\frac{1+{\mathbf{n}}_{p}\cdot{\mathbf{n}}_{p}^{\prime}}{2}\right)f_{p}f_{p}^{%
\prime}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>p</mi></munder><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>,</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></munder><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⋅</mo><msubsup><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: \noindent Demanding $\delta_{f_p} F$ to be non-negative determines the shape of the fermi surface: $f_p=1-\theta(\varepsilon_p)$. To vary $F$ with respect to ${\mathbf n}_p$ we add a set of Lagrange multipliers to enforce its unit length constraint: $F+\sum_p \lambda_p /2 {\mathbf n}_p^2$. The variation is:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle\delta_{f_{p}}F=\sum_{p}\varepsilon_{p}\delta f_{p}%
,\\
&\displaystyle\varepsilon_{p}\equiv v{\mathbf{n}}_{p}\cdot{\mathbf{p}}-\mu-{%
\mathbf{u}}\cdot{\mathbf{p}}-\frac{1}{A}\sum_{p^{\prime}}v_{p-p^{\prime}}\left%
(\frac{1+{\mathbf{n}}_{p}\cdot{\mathbf{n}}_{p}^{\prime}}{2}\right)f_{p}^{%
\prime}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>p</mi></munder><mrow><msub><mi>ε</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ε</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>≡</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mi>μ</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>𝐮</mi><mo>⋅</mo><mi>𝐩</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>A</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></munder><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⋅</mo><msubsup><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>f</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: \noindent Demanding this variation to be zero provides the following equation for the unit vector:
prevtext: \noindent Demanding $\delta_{f_p} F$ to be non-negative determines the shape of the fermi surface: $f_p=1-\theta(\varepsilon_p)$. To vary $F$ with respect to ${\mathbf n}_p$ we add a set of Lagrange multipliers to enforce its unit length constraint: $F+\sum_p \lambda_p /2 {\mathbf n}_p^2$. The variation is:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{split}&\displaystyle\delta_{{\mathbf{n}}_{p}}F=\sum_{p}[v({\mathbf{p}}-%
{\mathbf{K}}_{p})+\lambda_{p}{\mathbf{n}}_{p}]\cdot\delta{\mathbf{n}}_{p},\\
&\displaystyle v{\mathbf{K}}_{p}\equiv\frac{1}{2A}\sum_{p^{\prime}}v_{p-p^{%
\prime}}{\mathbf{n}}_{p^{\prime}}f_{p^{\prime}}.\end{split}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="0pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>δ</mi><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>p</mi></munder><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>𝐩</mi><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>𝐊</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>δ</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐊</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></mrow><mo>≡</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></munder><mrow><msub><mi>v</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>𝐧</mi><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><msup><mi>p</mi><mo>′</mo></msup></msub></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: \noindent Equations~\eqref{E}-\eqref{n} define a self-consistent loop determining the dispersion and the coherent combination of states being occupied. Substituting Eq.~\eqref{n} into Eq.~\eqref{E} leads to a more succinct expression for the dispersion:
prevtext: \noindent Demanding this variation to be zero provides the following equation for the unit vector:

nexttext:
\noindent The vector ${\mathbf K}_p$ is of central importance to this work. It is the same term responsible for the logarithmic corrections to the quasiparticle dispersion at the Dirac point when the system carries no current~\cite{Gonzalez94}. More crucially, ${\mathbf K}_p$ determines the location in momentum space of the Dirac point: ${\mathbf p}_D={\mathbf K}_{p_D}$. In the absence of current the self-consistent solution to this equation will be ${\mathbf p}_D=0$ but in the current carrying state the fact that ${\mathbf K}_{{\mathbf p}=0}\neq 0$ shows that Dirac point is displaced in momentum, therefore the current induces a {\it drag} in the Dirac point. 

The Dirac point Drag originates as a way for the system to save on the exchange energy cost imposed by the pseudo-spin vortex in momentum space. At zero current the fermi surface symmetrically surrounds the Dirac point and the pseudo-spin vortex core is pinned at its center at zero momentum. In the non-interacting limit, when the system is in a current carrying state, the fermi surface is deformed and its boundary in momentum space becomes closer to the vortex core. In the hole-doping case the states inside the fermi surface are unoccupied, and the occupied states closer to the fermi surface are responsible for most of the exchange energy cost. Therefore, when interactions are turned on the vortex core is pushed further into the center of the Fermi surface to save some of the exchange energy cost by making the pseudo-spins of states near the fermi surface closer to parallel. This picture is illustratred in the inset to Fig.~\ref{Kvsbeta}.

{\color{blue}{\em Perturbative estimates for the Dirac point Drag}}---In this section we will compute perturbatively in the strength of the Coulomb interaction the Dirac point Drag. In order to assess the impact of screening we employ the following simplified model for the screened Coulomb interaction:
prevtext: \noindent Equations~\eqref{E}-\eqref{n} define a self-consistent loop determining the dispersion and the coherent combination of states being occupied. Substituting Eq.~\eqref{n} into Eq.~\eqref{E} leads to a more succinct expression for the dispersion:

nexttext: \noindent where $\nu_F=g p_F/(2 \pi v)$ is the density of states of the non-interacting system at zero current, and $g=4$ accounts for the spin-valley degeneracy. To estimate ${\mathbf K}_p$ peturbatively we evaluate it from Eq.~\eqref{K} replacing in the right hand side the fermi surface and the pseudospin orientation of the non-interacting system: ${\mathbf n}_p^0=-\hat{\mathbf{p}}$. We obtain thus the Dirac point Drag to first order in the screened Coulomb interaction, ${\mathbf K}_0\equiv{\mathbf K}_{p=0}$, to be:
prevtext:
\noindent The vector ${\mathbf K}_p$ is of central importance to this work. It is the same term responsible for the logarithmic corrections to the quasiparticle dispersion at the Dirac point when the system carries no current~\cite{Gonzalez94}. More crucially, ${\mathbf K}_p$ determines the location in momentum space of the Dirac point: ${\mathbf p}_D={\mathbf K}_{p_D}$. In the absence of current the self-consistent solution to this equation will be ${\mathbf p}_D=0$ but in the current carrying state the fact that ${\mathbf K}_{{\mathbf p}=0}\neq 0$ shows that Dirac point is displaced in momentum, therefore the current induces a {\it drag} in the Dirac point. 

The Dirac point Drag originates as a way for the system to save on the exchange energy cost imposed by the pseudo-spin vortex in momentum space. At zero current the fermi surface symmetrically surrounds the Dirac point and the pseudo-spin vortex core is pinned at its center at zero momentum. In the non-interacting limit, when the system is in a current carrying state, the fermi surface is deformed and its boundary in momentum space becomes closer to the vortex core. In the hole-doping case the states inside the fermi surface are unoccupied, and the occupied states closer to the fermi surface are responsible for most of the exchange energy cost. Therefore, when interactions are turned on the vortex core is pushed further into the center of the Fermi surface to save some of the exchange energy cost by making the pseudo-spins of states near the fermi surface closer to parallel. This picture is illustratred in the inset to Fig.~\ref{Kvsbeta}.

{\color{blue}{\em Perturbative estimates for the Dirac point Drag}}---In this section we will compute perturbatively in the strength of the Coulomb interaction the Dirac point Drag. In order to assess the impact of screening we employ the following simplified model for the screened Coulomb interaction:

nexttext: \noindent where $\alpha=e^2/v$ is the effective fine structure constant of graphene. The perturbative expression in the case for the bare Coulomb interaction can be conveniently obtained from that above by taking $g\rightarrow 0$. Figure~\ref{Kvsbeta} depicts the behavior of the Dirac point drag as a function of $\beta$. The following is a good linear in $\beta$ approximation to Eq.~\eqref{K}:
prevtext: \noindent where $\nu_F=g p_F/(2 \pi v)$ is the density of states of the non-interacting system at zero current, and $g=4$ accounts for the spin-valley degeneracy. To estimate ${\mathbf K}_p$ peturbatively we evaluate it from Eq.~\eqref{K} replacing in the right hand side the fermi surface and the pseudospin orientation of the non-interacting system: ${\mathbf n}_p^0=-\hat{\mathbf{p}}$. We obtain thus the Dirac point Drag to first order in the screened Coulomb interaction, ${\mathbf K}_0\equiv{\mathbf K}_{p=0}$, to be:

&\displaystyle\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}}+\alpha g\sqrt{1-\beta^{2}}-%

prevtext: \noindent where $\alpha=e^2/v$ is the effective fine structure constant of graphene. The perturbative expression in the case for the bare Coulomb interaction can be conveniently obtained from that above by taking $g\rightarrow 0$. Figure~\ref{Kvsbeta} depicts the behavior of the Dirac point drag as a function of $\beta$. The following is a good linear in $\beta$ approximation to Eq.~\eqref{K}:

nexttext:
\noindent Where $U_0=1/A\sum_{p}v_{p}$ is a Hubbard-type on-site energy scale which is independent of $\mu,u$. To leading order in the interaction strength, we can re-express $\varepsilon_0$ and ${\mathbf K}_{0}$  in terms of the density $n$ and the current density ${\mathbf j}$, which are quantities directly accessible to experiment, by using the non-interacting expressions in Eq.~\eqref{n&j}.

At a fixed current density the parameter $\beta$ increases as the density approaches the Dirac point as $\sim \frac{1}{|n-n_D|}$. However, in realistic samples disorder-induced charge inhomogeneities become more prominent as the Dirac point is approached~\cite{Yacoby,Crommie}. Assuming $|n-n_D|\gtrsim 10^{12}$ cm$^{-2}$, which should be sufficient to ignore charge fluctuations in high quality samples such as those on boron-nitride substrates~\cite{Pablo}, and a current of $I=1$mA traversing a $1\mu$m wide sample, leads to an estimate $\beta \lesssim 0.6$. From Eq.~\eqref{K} this leads to an estimate of $|{\mathbf K}_{0}|\sim 10^{-3}$ \AA$^{-1}$. Therefore the effect is small but perhaps within reach of high resolution Angle-Resolved-Photoemission-Spectroscopy if it could be realized for samples in the presence of large current densities. 

{\color{blue}{\em Summary}}---We have described a many body approach to the current carrying states in the clean limit that is non-perturbative in the current but relies on the conservation of momentum for applying a quasi-equilibrium treatment. More specifically, we have studied quasiparticle self-energy effects in the current carrying states of interacting massless Dirac fermions. An interesting drag of the Dirac point arises as a mean for the system to reduce exchange energy. Although numerically small, the effect might be observable in high quality graphene samples in the regime of large current densities and small carrier densities and sufficiently away from the Dirac point to ignore disorder-induced charge inhomogeneities.
